questions.question: Question 1: Identify the organism.
questions.explanation:
.The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy. Treponemes are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals. Option A: Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends 
as shown in the image below 324 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Borrelia are large with irregular and wide open coils. Option D: Helicobacter pylori is a spiral rod (bacilli) that is not classified as a spirochete.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 30-year-old truck driver presented with a painless ulcer in the genital area. On 
examination, a single ulcer with an indurated base was found. An image of the tissue section 
is shown below. Identify the staining method. 316 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by Levaditi's method. Single painless 
ulcer with indurated base points towards the diagnosis of syphilis. Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted 
infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis. It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. • Fontana's method is used on smear • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections The clinical manifestations of syphilis include: Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule 
that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous 
consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer. Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. 
The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may 
persist for months. Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and 
generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally 
pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, 
malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or 
later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the 325 
Sold by @itachibot classic iritis or uveitis. Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent 
syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed 
the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman 
may infect the fetus in utero. Neurosyphilis: The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, 
meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis. Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic 
regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis. Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or 
“snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray 
examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice, 
thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention 
(CDC): • Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL), • Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response 
to therapy (RPR or VDRL) • Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, 
TPHA, EIA/CIA) Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

questions.question: Question 3: What type of motility is shown by Treponema pallidum?
questions.explanation:
Treponema pallidum show corkscrew motility, i.e movement by rotation around the long axis. The characteristic feature of spirochetes is the presence of endoflagella, situated between the 
outer membrane and cell wall, that facilitates this movement. 326 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 32-year-old pregnant lady tests VDRL positive at her 1st-trimester antenatal check-up. An 
FTA-ABS confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is a false statement about the 
organism causing this disease?

options.a: It cannot be cultured in vitro
options.b: Endoflagella is in the periplasmic space.
options.c: Humans are the only known natural hosts

questions.explanation:
VDRL positive status is suggestive of syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum. Fluorescent 
treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) is a confirmatory test. Reiter’s strain is a cultivable, non-pathogenic treponeme, showing morphological and antigenic 
similarities with T.pallidum. It is widely used as the antigen in group-specific treponemal tests for 
the diagnosis of syphilis. Nichol's strain is virulent and non-cultivable in artificial media. However, it can be grown in cell 
culture through serial passage in live rabbit testes.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient had a solitary, painless penile ulcer 2 months back. Now, he presents with a 
generalized maculopapular rash over the body. What is the sensitivity of VDRL at this stage of 
the disease?
questions.explanation:
The sensitivity of VDRL is 100% in secondary syphilis. History of solitary painless ulcer with a 
generalized maculopapular rash is consistent with secondary syphilis. The VDRL test becomes positive 4–5 weeks after exposure to T. pallidum and 1–2 weeks after the 
appearance of the chancre. The VDRL test is a highly sensitive test. The sensitivity of the test depends on the stage of the 
disease: • Primary syphilis- 60–75% • Secondary syphilis- 100% • High antibody titers may be found in patients developing gummatous lesions and neurovascular 
or cardiovascular complications. • Tertiary syphilis- usually negative • Negative test: 327 
Sold by @itachibot • Early primary syphilis • Latent acquired syphilis • Late congenital syphilis Secondary syphilis is the most infective stage in the course of the illness. The patient may present 
with a roseolar or papular skin rash, condyloma lata, and mucous patches. The image below shows lesions of secondary syphilis.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the serological tests of syphilis?

options.a: Rapid plasma reagin test is a group specific treponemal test
options.b: VDRL test is the test of choice for response to therapy
options.c: VDRL is the test of choice for examining CSF
options.d: Treponemal tests are likely to remain reactive even after adequate therapy

questions.explanation:
RPR is a non-specific test. It uses the VDRL antigen (cardiolipin) containing carbon particles. 
Hence, results can be seen by the naked eye, whereas VDRL requires a microscope for 
visualization of flocculation. The test of choice for monitoring response to treatment and for examining CSF is VDRL The test of choice for syphilis screening is RPR. After treatment, in early syphilis, • Non-treponemal tests- titers decline or become non-reactive • Treponemal tests- remain reactive For diagnosis of syphilis, a 2 test approach is used i.e., screening with an NTT (non-treponemal 
test) which includes either VDRL or RPR. Confirmation of syphilis is done by a treponemal test, 
most commonly by TPHA (Treponema pallidum hemagglutination test). Follow-up is done using NTT (as treponemal tests remains positive for years after treatment).

questions.question:
Question 7: A 55-year old man was brought to the OPD with complaints of rapid decline in cognition, 
impaired position, and vibratory sense. There is a history of sporadic short-term relationships 
with many promiscuous sexual partners. Romberg’s sign is positive and bilateral Argyll 
Robertson pupils are seen on checking for pupillary reflex. Which of the following is the 
investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
328 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical scenario given above with a positive sexual history, Romberg test, and Argyll 
Robertson pupils is suggestive of neurosyphilis. The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis 
is VDRL. The CSF VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of 
neurosyphilis. Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for: • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/L). • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL). • CSF VDRL reactivity.

questions.question:
Question 8: You treated a case of secondary syphilis with a single dose of benzathine penicillin-G 2.4 
million IU IM. What follow-up advice would you give for the assessment of the patient's 318 
Sold by @itachibot response to treatment?

options.a: Follow up with VDRL after 6 months and 12 months
options.b: Follow up with VDRL after 3 months and 6 months
options.c: Follow up with TPHA after 6 months and 12 months
options.d: Follow up with TPHA after 3 months and 6 months

questions.explanation:
The investigation used to assess response to treatment in syphilis is VDRL. In the case of 
secondary syphilis, follow-up VDRL should be done at 6 months and 12 months. VDRL and RPR become negative after adequate treatment whereas specific treponemal tests 
remain positive indefinitely despite treatment. Guidelines for follow up: • Patients with primary or secondary syphilis should be examined 6 and 12 months after 
treatment. • Patients with latent or late syphilis should be examined at 6, 12, and 24 months after treatment.

questions.question:
Question 9: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestational age tested VDRL positive but negative for 
specific treponemal tests. What is your interpretation?
questions.explanation:
Pregnancy can give rise to false-positive VDRL. Biological false-positive (BFP) reactions are defined as positive reactions obtained in 
non-specific treponemal tests (RPR, VDRL) with negative results in specific treponemal tests, in 
the absence of past or present treponemal infections and not caused by technical faults.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 2-month-old infant presented with a runny nose and bullous lesions on the skin and legs. 
Her X-ray (given below) showed features suggestive of periostitis. Which of the following is 
the initial investigation of choice?
questions.explanation:
The newborn baby has characteristic signs and symptoms of congenital syphilis. Periostitis is a 
hallmark of skeletal manifestation. VDRL or RPR is the initial investigation of choice in 
congenital syphilis. The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous 
lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; 
hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. All neonates born to mothers who have reactive nontreponemal and treponemal test results 
should be evaluated with a quantitative nontreponemal serologic test (RPR or VDRL) performed 329 
Sold by @itachibot on the neonate’s serum, because umbilical cord blood can become contaminated with maternal 
blood and yield a false-positive result. FTA-ABS or TPHA is used for confirmation of syphilis in a patient with reactive RPR or VDRL 
test. T. pallidum cannot be detected by culture.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the causative agent of yaws ?
questions.explanation:
Causative agent of yaws is Treponema pertenue. It is one of the endemic treponematoses that spreads by direct contact. The image shows ulcerative skin lesions seen in yaws. Causative age 
nt Disease T. pertenue 
Yaws T. pallidum 
Venereal syphili 
s T. carateum 
Pinta Endemic syphili 
s T. endemicu 
m

questions.question: Question 12: What is the causative organism and the corresponding vector for epidemic relapsing fever?
questions.explanation:
Epidemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia recurrentis and is transmitted by louse. 330 
Sold by @itachibot Endemic relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia duttoni, Borrelia hermsii, Borrelia parkeri, etc, and 
is transmitted by ticks.

questions.question:
Question 13: During a louse outbreak among jail inmates, a few of them developed fevers that subsided 
after 3-5 days. The fever relapsed after a week and subsided again. Many patients had tender 
splenomegaly on examination. Which culture medium is used to isolate the organism 
implicated here?

options.d: Mannitol, egg-yolk, phenol red, polymyxin agar

questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of louse-born relapsing fever (LBRF) caused by Borrelia 
recurrentis. Barbour-Stoenner-Kelly broth medium is used to isolate all Borrelia species except for 
B.miyaotoi. Tender splenomegaly and relapsing fever in the background of a louse outbreak point towards the 
diagnosis of LBRF. It was very common during wars and in the jails of former days but with improvements in hygiene 
and the discovery of insecticides, it has now become rare.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which one of the following micro-organisms uses antigenic variation as a major means of 
evading the host immune system? 320 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Borrelia recurrentis uses antigenic variation as a major means of evading the host immune 
system. It causes relapsing fever. Borrelia readily undergoes antigenic variations in vivo and this is believed to be the reason for the 
occurrence of relapses in the disease. Antigenic variations occur because of DNA rearrangements 
in linear plasmids present in borrelia.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 23 year old presented with fever, myalgia, and skin lesion as shown in the image. What is 
the causative organism for the above condition?
questions.explanation:
The image shows erythema migrans, seen in Lyme disease. It is caused by Borrelia Burgdoferi. The lesion has a target center with partial central clearing and a bright red outer border. It 
usually begins as a red macule or papule at the site of the tick bite. The tick implicated is the black-legged tick, Ixodes scapularis, shown in the image below. 331 
Sold by @itachibot The most severe manifestation of Lyme disease is Lyme neuroborreliosis (LNB), reported in 10–
15% of individuals with localized erythema migrans. The activation of the inflammatory response 
in LNB contributes to the pathogenesis of a broad spectrum of neurologic disorders.

questions.question:
Question 16: Following a flood, there is an outbreak of fever. Water samples from various sources are 
being studied for pathogens. The bacteria shown in the given image was isolated as a 
potential cause of disease. Which of the following animals is the most important reservoir of 
these organisms? 321 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The electron micrograph shows the spirochete, Leptospira interrogans, which causes the 
water-borne disease, leptospirosis. Rats are the most important reservoir. Transmission of leptospires may follow direct contact with urine, blood, or tissue from an infected 
animal or exposure to environmental contamination.

questions.question:
Question 17: A farmer who works in paddy fields presented with fever, intense myalgia, and hematochezia. 
Lab investigations showed sharply elevated creatinine levels and high liver enzymes. What is 
the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Weil's disease which is caused by leptospira. Long hours of working in a field with water (paddy field), is a high-risk factor for the development 
of leptospirosis. Weil’s syndrome is the severe form of leptospirosis that encompasses the triad of hemorrhage, 
jaundice, and acute kidney injury. The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

questions.question:
Question 18: At a relief camp in Karnataka, a few people developed fever, myalgia, and conjunctival 
suffusion. Rapid diagnostic IgM ELISA tests performed in the field showed leptospirosis. 
Which of the following culture media can be used to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris (EMJH) media is the culture medium used for 
leptospira. 332 
Sold by @itachibot Other culture media that can be used are Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media. The image below shows EMJH medium, with Dinger's ring/zone. The growth of the leptospires is 
at a maximum density at this zone. It is identified as an area of increased turbidity, beneath the 
surface of the semi-solid medium. It is the zone of optimum oxygen tension for the growth of the 
bacteria.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 
days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis 
(Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis. Serotype-specific tests: • Microscopic agglutination test • Macroscopic agglutination test Option A: Widal test is used to screen for typhoid fever Option C: Weil-Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers Option D: Paul-Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 12-year-old boy presents with right upper quadrant pain, calf pain, conjunctival suffusion, 
icterus, and fever. Examination shows tender hepatomegaly. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is leptospirosis. Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild 
disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, 
abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, 
abdomen, and back. Mild cases can be treated with oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin. 333 
Sold by @itachibot Severe leptospirosis is rapidly progressive and is associated with high fatality. The classic 
presentation of the severe disease called Weil’s syndrome includes the triad of hemorrhage, 
jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Jaundice when present can be profound and physical 
examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation /relative 
bradycardia can be seen. Moderate to severe cases are treated with intravenous penicillin, 
ampicillin, or ceftriaxone. The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis. Leptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They are 
thin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is by 
microscopic agglutination test. Transmission occurs through cuts or breaks in the skin and mucous membranes (conjunctival and 
oral mucosa). Several outbreaks have been reported that resulted from exposure to floodwaters 
contaminated by urine from infected animals. The organism enters the bloodstream and lodges in 
the parenchymatous organs (liver and kidneys) leading to hemorrhage and necrosis of the tissue 334 
Sold by @itachibot causing dysfunction of the organs. The lifecycle of Leptospira is shown below. Illness is classically biphasic after an incubation period of up to 1 month. The stages are: • Acute leptospiremic phase- the organism can be cultured from blood. • Resolving immune phase- the organism can be cultured from urine. The stages may not be clinically distinguishable. Other options: Option A - Chikungunya is a viral disease that presents with saddle-back fever, conjunctival 
suffusion, and photophobia. Migratory arthralgia, especially involving small joints may also be 
seen. A maculopapular or petechial rash is frequently seen on the trunk. Option C - Dengue hemorrhagic fever is a form of severe dengue with bleeding manifestations. 
Evidence of plasma leakage and thrombocytopenia is also generally seen. Option D - Encephalitis due to Hepatitis A is seen in fulminant hepatitis, a rare complication. 
Patients present with confusion, disorientation, ascites, and edema. 335 
Sold by @itachibot General Properties of Viruses
